definition: Wang Meng (325-375), prime minister to Fu Jian 苻堅|苻坚[Fu2 Jian1] of Former Qin 前秦[Qian2 Qin2]
surname Wang
king or monarch/best or strongest of its type/grand/great
to rule/to reign over
ferocious/fierce/violent/brave/suddenly/abrupt/(slang) awesome
Fu Jian (338-385), emperor of Former Qin 前秦[Qian2 Qin2], reigning from 357-385
Cheng Yu (141-220), advisor to General Cao Cao 曹操 during the Three Kingdoms era
Wang Ping (1962-2013), PRC crosstalk actor

Zhang Hua (232-300), Western Jin writer, poet and politician/Zhang Hua (1958-1982), student held up as a martyr after he died saving an old peasant from a septic tank/other Zhang Hua's too numerous to mention
Shi Le, founder of Later Zhao of the Sixteen Kingdoms 後趙|后赵 (319-350)
Li Delin (530-590), historian of Northern Wei and Sui dynasty
Wang Dun (266-324), powerful general of Jin dynasty and brother of civil official Wang Dao 王導|王导, subsequently rebellious warlord 322-324
Zhao Qi (-201 BC), early Han commentator on Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3]
Kong Rong (153-208), poet of the Three Kingdoms period
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Former Qin of the Sixteen Kingdoms (351-395)
Huangfu Song (-195), later Han general and warlord
Qin general Meng Tian (-210 BC), involved in 215 BC in fighting the Northern Xiongnu 匈奴 and building the great wall
Yuan Shao (153-202), general during late Han, subsequently warlord
Zhou Bo (?-169 BC), military man and politician at the Qin-Han transition, a founding minister of Western Han
Dong Zhuo (-192), top general of late Han, usurped power in 189, murdered empress dowager and child emperor, killed in 192 by Lü Bu 呂布|吕布
